sundaram subramanian wrote:
>
> Hello Michael,
> Thanks for the explanation. That is exactly what i was looking for.!!
> Is there any way I can instruct Heritrix to follow specific character 
> encoding for specific domain i am crawling .
>





You mean, change the default encoding so that it is other than 8bit 
ISO-8859-1 by default? (See this line, 
http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/crawler/fetcher/FetchHTTP.html#168) 


You can't change it via the UI (It would be easy enough making a patch 
to add this feature). You could change the hard-coding in the source.

This would make it so that if the website did not volunteer an encoding, 
then we'd use whatever DEFAULT_CONTENT_CHARSET was set to (This won't 
help you if the site is volunteering the incorrect charset. Is that the 
case?).


>
> Does heritrix looks at the charset encoding specified in the META tag 
> of the crawled HTML?
>





No. Not currently.

If you want to help out, there's movement in 
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=899909&group_id=73833&atid=539102 
<http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=899909&group_id=73833&atid=539102.> 
Check it out. Kohei TAKETA has added a promising patch that makes use of 
a java implementation of mozilla universal charset detection. You might 
like to take the patch for a run and see how it does for you reporting 
back to the issue your experience?

Thanks,
St.Ack


>
> */Michael Stack <stack@...>/* wrote:
>
>     Hello Thiru:
>
>     There may be some misunderstanding.
>
>     Heritrix does its best at downloading whatever is presented by the
>     server saving to disk exactly what was served. No conversion is
>     done on
>     the raw downloads. This is intentional. We're trying 'archive'
>     exactly
>     what we read from the servers.
>
>     Later when processors run, they want to do various analysis
>     against the
>     downloaded content: e.g. the ExtractorHTML will try and pull links
>     out
>     of HTML pages. Dependent on the processor, they'll want to look at
>     the
>     download as characters rather than as raw bytes. For example, they
>     may
>     want to regex over a character stream to find links. At this time,
>     we'll provide a charset to the character reader so it does
>     appropriate
>     translation of raw bytes. Regards the charset, Heritrix is a little
>     lame. We just use the charset from the HTTP Response headers. If
>     none,
>     we default to ISO-8859-1. The charset on the HTTP Response is very
>     often wrong so when processors go to read, they'll be reading mangled
>     characters.
>
>     We have an RFE to add a charset guesser to the processing stream:
>     http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=899909&group_id=73833&atid=539102.
>     <http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=899909&group_id=73833&atid=539102.>
>
>     Is this what you were thinking?
>     Yours,
>     St.Ack
